instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.R7151: What is R7151? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7152: What is R7152? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.820-2330: What is 820-2330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Can't see battery.
threads.message:
This board originally had a liquid spill on pins 5 & 6 of the battery connector.
I cleaned it up and it worked again, till it came back with not seeing the battery.

J6950::5 = 0.052 (this is low to a similar board of a different model)
J6950::6 = OL

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Can't see battery.
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R5380</RESISTOR>::2 Diode mode = 0.053, is that a bit low?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Can't see battery.
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R5380</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5381</RESISTOR> ohm?

threads.message:
[QUOTE="Repairable, post: 22009"]<RESISTOR>R5380</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5381</RESISTOR> ohm?

[/QUOTE]

1.95k each.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Can't see battery.
threads.message:
diode mode with no battery and charger i asume?
tested a differnt battery? (i think this is stil the battery that was in it when it got liqued damaged?)

ISL area

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Can't see battery.
threads.message:
[QUOTE="Repairable, post: 22012"]diode mode with no battery and charger i asume?
tested a differnt battery? (i think this is stil the battery that was in it when it got liqued damaged?)

ISL area[/QUOTE]

Diode earlier above wit no charger or battery.
Tested with new known good battery.

ISL area looks clean and I never saw any damage there initially.

<CHIP>U7100</CHIP>::17/18 == 3ohms
That's too low right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Can't see battery.
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7151</RESISTOR>  2.2
<RESISTOR>R7152</RESISTOR>   0
<RESISTOR>R7150</RESISTOR>  0.01
5% difference allowed.....


<TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR> ?
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> (measure with battery only, and charger only and together)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Can't see battery.
threads.message:
Resisters you mentioned all measure correct.

Adapter Only
<TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR>::1 = 8.19
<TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR>::2 = 8.19
<TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR>::3 = 8.19
<TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR>::4 = 8.19
<TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR>::5 = UNSTABLE

Bat Only
<TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR>::1 = 8.05
<TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR>::2 = 8.05
<TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR>::3 = 8.05
<TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR>::4 = 1.57
<TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR>::5 = 8.05

Bat & Adapter
<TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR>::1 = 8.19
<TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR>::2 = 8.19
<TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR>::3 = 8.19
<TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR>::4 = 7.55
<TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR>::5 = 155 - 165 mV - Unstable

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Can't see battery.
threads.message: Diode mode on both data pins on the battery connector? This is either a bad SMC/<CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> or crap under the SMC.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Can't see battery.
threads.message:
Data pins being pin 5 & 6?

::4 = 0.450
::5 = 0.076
::6 = OL

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Can't see battery.
threads.message: pin 5 is shorted to ground by either the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> or the smc. one way to find out.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Can't see battery.
threads.message:
Ugh, my success rate of replacing ISLs is really low.
I picked up from one of your videos recently to press down to make sure the chip is snug and flat on the board before removing the heat.

Will try it with this board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Can't see battery.
threads.message:
Without the ISL on, I get 0.141 in diode mode on.

So short is gone, that still seems a little low to me, but magnitudes of order better than we were.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Can't see battery.
threads.message:
I swapped the ISL, I get an green / orange light but now the board will only run off the battery.

When I plug the battery in, it boots up like it's on mains.

Any ideas?


Edit;
I reseated the ISL and we're back to not seeing or running off the battery just like before.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Can't see battery.
threads.message: Take some old POS <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> or something and practice removing the ISL and soldering it back on. When you can do that five times in a row come back to this one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Can't see battery.
threads.message:
So is the issue poor soldering or is there another problem somewhere else?

Diode mode reads 0.141 which seems low still to me, I don't have another board to check with.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Can't see battery.
threads.message: I guess you are with black probe to ground, in this case both data lines should give you OL reading, with red probe to ground (wich is the right way to do it), you should have about  0.500....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Can't see battery.
threads.message:
I have the red probe on ground.

So 0.140 is too low then. :/
SMC issue?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Can't see battery.
threads.message: Probably killed the ISL, remove and measure again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Can't see battery.
threads.message:
It reads 0.140 with the ISL removed too.


EDIT:
Replaced the ISL again with a fresh new one and now get a reading of 0.225

But <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> heats up a lot as soon as I add power. Could this be a faulty <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> or a symptom of another problem?

<TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> does of course have a path straight to ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Can't see battery.
threads.message:
Swapped <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>.

Fan spun for a few second then went dead. Pretty sure I heard a sizzling sound. :/

<TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>::8 = OL, pretty sure it had a reading earlier.
It's getting hot again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Can't see battery.
threads.message:
Of course it fried again because the ISL is dead or not soldered properly, you swap them both.
At this point the SMC seems to be dead too. This all happened due to crappy soldering :(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Can't see battery.
threads.message:
My soldering is a work of art this time. If nothing else I have definitely learnt how to solder these chips down well.

First attempt was appalling though.


Anyway, I'll swap both the ISL and <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> together and see how it goes.

Is it standard practise to swap both chips together?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Can't see battery.
threads.message: If the FET is dead then always swap the driver chip too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Can't see battery.
threads.message: Don't want to sound stupid jumping in here, I have the same problem same board and I've been following this along and I too replaced the ISL good soldering without replacing the FETs and wanted to be sure that in general replace the ISL along with the Inrush Limiter and the Reverse-Current Protection FETs?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Can't see battery.
threads.message: No. This was a poorly done video, but it explains the logic going on here. [url]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iot4lO1Nork[/url] start from 7:30

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Can't see battery.
threads.message:
I managed to get the customer a replacement board.

Will continue with this one to see if I can repair it anyway. Worst case my soldering improves and I get a donor board.

So my next step is to replace the ISL and <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR> simultaneously and see if I get a different result.
